channel.title: ASF Jira
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [LOG4J2-1051] NoClassDefFoundError when starting app on Google App Engine
item.description:
I have an app that uses

  • log4j-api
  • log4j-core
  • log4j-web

and after deploying it to GAE I see such exception in the logs

2015-06-10 23:01:05.768
Uncaught exception from servlet
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: Could not initialize class org.apache.logging.log4j.core.util.Loader
	at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.lookup.Interpolator.<init>(Interpolator.java:114)
	at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config.AbstractConfiguration.<init>(AbstractConfiguration.java:105)
	at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config.NullConfiguration.<init>(NullConfiguration.java:30)
	at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.LoggerContext.<clinit>(LoggerContext.java:62)
	at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.selector.ClassLoaderContextSelector.locateContext(ClassLoaderContextSelector.java:145)
	at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.selector.ClassLoaderContextSelector.getContext(ClassLoaderContextSelector.java:70)
	at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.selector.ClassLoaderContextSelector.getContext(ClassLoaderContextSelector.java:57)
	at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.impl.Log4jContextFactory.getContext(Log4jContextFactory.java:142)
	at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.impl.Log4jContextFactory.getContext(Log4jContextFactory.java:42)
	at org.apache.logging.log4j.LogManager.getContext(LogManager.java:175)
	at org.apache.logging.log4j.LogManager.getLogger(LogManager.java:426)
	at org.apache.struts2.tiles.StrutsTilesListener.<clinit>(StrutsTilesListener.java:50)
	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(NativeConstructorAccessorImpl.java:57)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.newInstance(DelegatingConstructorAccessorImpl.java:45)
	at java.lang.reflect.Constructor.newInstance(Constructor.java:526)
	at java.lang.Class.newInstance(Class.java:375)
	at org.mortbay.jetty.webapp.WebXmlConfiguration.newListenerInstance(WebXmlConfiguration.java:650)
	at org.mortbay.jetty.webapp.WebXmlConfiguration.initListener(WebXmlConfiguration.java:631)
	at org.mortbay.jetty.webapp.WebXmlConfiguration.initWebXmlElement(WebXmlConfiguration.java:368)
	at org.mortbay.jetty.webapp.WebXmlConfiguration.initialize(WebXmlConfiguration.java:289)
	at org.mortbay.jetty.webapp.WebXmlConfiguration.configure(WebXmlConfiguration.java:222)
	at org.mortbay.jetty.webapp.WebXmlConfiguration.configureWebApp(WebXmlConfiguration.java:180)
	at org.mortbay.jetty.webapp.WebAppContext.startContext(WebAppContext.java:1247)
	at org.mortbay.jetty.handler.ContextHandler.doStart(ContextHandler.java:517)
	at org.mortbay.jetty.webapp.WebAppContext.doStart(WebAppContext.java:467)
	at org.mortbay.component.AbstractLifeCycle.start(AbstractLifeCycle.java:50)
	at com.google.apphosting.runtime.jetty.AppVersionHandlerMap.createHandler(AppVersionHandlerMap.java:199)
	at com.google.apphosting.runtime.jetty.AppVersionHandlerMap.getHandler(AppVersionHandlerMap.java:174)
	at com.google.apphosting.runtime.jetty.JettyServletEngineAdapter.serviceRequest(JettyServletEngineAdapter.java:134)
	at com.google.apphosting.runtime.JavaRuntime$RequestRunnable.run(JavaRuntime.java:527)
	at com.google.tracing.TraceContext$TraceContextRunnable.runInContext(TraceContext.java:437)
	at com.google.tracing.TraceContext$TraceContextRunnable$1.run(TraceContext.java:444)
	at com.google.tracing.CurrentContext.runInContext(CurrentContext.java:230)
	at com.google.tracing.TraceContext$AbstractTraceContextCallback.runInInheritedContextNoUnref(TraceContext.java:308)
	at com.google.tracing.TraceContext$AbstractTraceContextCallback.runInInheritedContext(TraceContext.java:300)
	at com.google.tracing.TraceContext$TraceContextRunnable.run(TraceContext.java:441)
	at com.google.apphosting.runtime.ThreadGroupPool$PoolEntry.run(ThreadGroupPool.java:251)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
item.environment: master branch, JDK7, Google App Engine, Apache Struts 2.5
item.summary: NoClassDefFoundError when starting app on Google App Engine

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: No clue what's wrong

Can this be set up as GAE unit test in our Maven build?

I take it that you are using the latest sources, it would be good to note that in the description.

It's likely that an exception was thrown while initializing the Log4j Loader class. We need to see that exception or error.

Ah, I see this in Loader:

    static {
        final SecurityManager sm = System.getSecurityManager();
        if (sm != null) {
            sm.checkPermission(new RuntimePermission("getStackTrace"));
            sm.checkPermission(new ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks"));
        }
    }

and I bet that checkPermission throws a SecurityException and we do not see it.

I'm not sure why these perms are checked and not saved.

Just for grins, you could remove the static block and see what happens.

Looking at the openjdk 7u40 sources, I see:

jaxws\src\share\jaxws_classes\com\sun\xml\internal\ws\model\AbstractWrapperBeanGenerator.java:        skipProperties.add("getStackTrace");
jdk\src\share\classes\java\lang\Thread.java:     * <tt>RuntimePermission("getStackTrace")</tt> permission
jdk\src\share\classes\java\lang\Thread.java:     * <tt>RuntimePermission("getStackTrace")</tt> permission as well as
jdk\src\share\classes\sun\security\tools\policytool\PolicyTool.java:                "getStackTrace",
jdk\src\share\classes\sun\security\util\SecurityConstants.java:       new RuntimePermission("getStackTrace");

and Loader does do any calls to getStackTrace(), so why do we need the check in the static init?

remkop@yahoo.com? ralphgoers? jvz? Thoughts?

I'm pretty sure Matt added this. Unfortunately he is unavailable. However, I know he was adding permission checks to make sure we wouldn't blow up all over the place with SecurityExceptions. The fact that this blows up with a NoClassDefFoundError and doesn't identify the problem definitely needs to be addressed.

I'm thinking that this class used to do more than it does now and the checks are now irrelevant. Or that is is WIP.

We do want to run on GAE, so we should try to degrade behavior like LoaderUtil now does instead of blowing up in a static initializer which helps no one.

Hopefully, lukaszlenart will reply soon with the result of the experiment I suggested.

I do miss Matt. I hope he is OK.

There is no JMX on GAE right. Same with Android. Now we're getting somewhere.

I do think that we can remove the checks in Loader now. I'll do that at least and we can keep on going.

There is no JMX on GAE right. Same with Android. Now we're getting somewhere.

I do think that we can remove the checks in Loader now. I'll do that at least and we can keep on going.

I have tried disable JMX by setting system properties in appengine-web.xml

  <system-properties>
    <property name="log4j2.disable.jmx" value="true"/>
  </system-properties

and by defining a property in log4j2.component.properties

log4j2.disable.jmx=true

but it didn't help ;(

We now catch NoClassDefFoundError and rethrow it as a IAE when trying to load a plugin like JmxRuntimeInputArgumentsLookup, which depends on JMX. On platforms like Google App Engine and Android, some JRE classes are not supported: JMX, JNDI, etc.

Please try again with the latest from Git master.

In the case of the JmxRuntimeInputArgumentsLookup class, log4j does not know it is a JMX dependent class. We could add some kind of @Plugin attribute to mark the class as a JMX class and then have log4j check for that vs. log4j2.disable.jmx=true but I think the fix I have in now is more bullet-proof as it will not bring down the calling app.

The result is still the same, problem with loading JMX

Are you sure you built jars from the latest sources?

We catch the NoClassDefFoundError:

    public static <T> T instantiate(final Class<T> clazz) {
        Objects.requireNonNull(clazz, "No class provided");
        final Constructor<T> constructor = getDefaultConstructor(clazz);
        try {
            return constructor.newInstance();
        } catch (final NoClassDefFoundError e) {
            // LOG4J2-1051
            // On platforms like Google App Engine and Android, some JRE classes are not supported: JMX, JNDI, etc.
            throw new IllegalArgumentException(e);
        } catch (final InstantiationException e) {
            throw new IllegalArgumentException(e);
        } catch (final IllegalAccessException e) {
            throw new IllegalStateException(e);
        } catch (final InvocationTargetException e) {
            Throwables.rethrow(e.getCause());
            throw new InternalError("Unreachable");
        }
    }

Did you push the changes? I don't see anything like that here https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=logging-log4j2.git;a=blob;f=log4j-core/src/main/java/org/apache/logging/log4j/core/util/ReflectionUtil.java
Oops, good guess. I just pushed upstream.
Now it works! Great!
Good! I'll say the usual "Please verify and close".

Problem is here

    /**
     * Constructs an Interpolator using a given StrLookup and a list of packages to find Lookup plugins in.
     *
     * @param defaultLookup  the default StrLookup to use as a fallback
     * @param pluginPackages a list of packages to scan for Lookup plugins
     * @since 2.1
     */
    public Interpolator(final StrLookup defaultLookup, final List<String> pluginPackages) {
        this.defaultLookup = defaultLookup == null ? new MapLookup(new HashMap<String, String>()) : defaultLookup;
        final PluginManager manager = new PluginManager(CATEGORY);
        manager.collectPlugins(pluginPackages);
        final Map<String, PluginType<?>> plugins = manager.getPlugins();

        for (final Map.Entry<String, PluginType<?>> entry : plugins.entrySet()) {
            try {
                final Class<? extends StrLookup> clazz = entry.getValue().getPluginClass().asSubclass(StrLookup.class);
                lookups.put(entry.getKey(), ReflectionUtil.instantiate(clazz));
            } catch (final Exception ex) {
                LOGGER.error("Unable to create Lookup for {}", entry.getKey(), ex);
            }
        }
    }

this constructor doesn't follow the safe logic in second constructor public Interpolator(final Map<String, String> properties)

As far I understand is due to introducing support for plugins but it would be more useful to exclude plugin names instead of packages. log4j.plugin.packages is useless if you have plugins in the same package - org.apache.logging.log4j.core.lookup contains wanted and unwanted plugins :\

Fixed in master in commit edc7925: the same error handling is used regardless of which constructor was called.

Please verify and close.
Cool, thanks - I will check and report back.
Do you publish snapshots? I don't see it here https://repository.apache.org/content/groups/snapshots/org/apache/logging/log4j/log4j-api/

I don't know how publishing snapshots works to be honest.
You can check out the source and build with mvn clean install (or mvn -DskipTests clean install which is 10 minutes faster).
Jenkins publishes the snapshots. The latest build is for 2.6.3-SNAPSHOT and was published today. We haven't modified the pom's for 2.7. I'll do that when the release is done.
Confirmed, no more problems spotted, thanks!
